title: Acceleron Gives Up on Rare Genetic Disease. Analysts Are Still Bullish on the Stock.
text:
Text size

Shares of Acceleron Pharma are plummeting after the biotech ﻿ company said it was discontinuing development of an experimental drug meant to treat facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy, a rare genetic disease.

While some analysts dropped their price targets for Acceleron (ticker: XLRN) on the news, many remained bullish. Still, the stock fell 6.8% in premarket trading.

Cowen analyst Yaron Werber said there had been skepticism of the drug, called ACE-083, even before this week’s news. “We think the termination of further development is a clearing event as investors have been worrying that further development will be costly and unlikely to yield approval,” Werber wrote in a research note on Monday evening,.

The back story. Shares of Acceleron are up 2.5% so far this year, trailing behind the iShares NASDAQ Biotechnology ETF (IBB), which is up 9%, and the S&P 500, up 19.6%. The company, which currently has no approved drugs, has a deal with Celgene (CELG) to develop luspatercept, Acceleron’s lead drug candidate, which would tread serious blood disorders.

What’s new. On Monday, Acceleron said in a statement that ACE-083 failed to achieve “statistically significant improvements in functional endpoints relative to placebo” in a Phase 2 trial of the drug in patients with facioscapulohermal muscular dystrophy.

“We are certainly disappointed with these results,” Habib Dable, Acceleron’s president and CEO, said in a statement. “Unfortunately, in this case, the data show no evidence of such a benefit and, therefore, do not support further development of ACE-083 for FSHD.”

The company is expecting Phase 2 data on the drug in another rare disease, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, in the first quarter of next year.

In a note on Tuesday, Citi Research analyst Yigal Nochomovitz cut his price target on Acceleron to $52, from $61, but maintained a Buy rating on the stock. “The FSHD failure was in-line with our expectations,” Nochomovitz wrote. He said he cut his target for the stock price after removing from his model revenues for the drug from both facioscapulohermal muscular dystrophy and Charcot-Marie-Tooth.

SVB Leerink analyst Geoffrey Porges cut his price target on Acceleron to $55 from $62, but maintained his Outperform rating. JPMorgan ’s Eric Joseph, meanwhile, cut his price target to $56 from $58. He also kept the stock at Overweigh.

Looking ahead. In his note on Tuesday, JPMorgan’s Joseph wrote that investors’ focus for the company is “primarily on luspatercept.”

“Long-term, we remain fundamentally bullish on the commercial potential of luspatercept across a diversity of dysplastic anemia indications (under-reflected at current levels), which forms the basis of our Overweight rating,” Joseph wrote.
